div1.head: Jim to Mademoiselle Marcelle Guerin, Sunday [June 18, 1916]
div1.p: Bill Thaw brought out the box of candy. I thank you so much Marcelle for thinking of me in such a delightful way. I enjoyed it immensely.

We have been so busy since the good weather came that there has been no time to write. Day before yesterday we were six hours in the air and on alert rest of the twenty four. I’m on guard this morning and since four have been going up on false alarms.

That fellow Chapman is a wonder. He’s so brave he’s unique — Kiffin says he’s too courageous and will suffer for it. Yesterday he attacked a Boche over the lines and was immediately surrounded by four others. As he was trying to get away a Fokker swooped down from above and filled him full of holes. One of the aileron controls was cut off and he had to work it with one hand. Another bullet ripped his fusilage [sic] just back of him and another went thru [sic] his wind shield and grazed his head wounding him slightly. There were other balls all thru [sic] his machine. He finally escaped and then fired back to show he was not wounded badly nor brought down. He landed at a nearby field, was repaired and flew home.
We are anxious about Balsley at this moment. There was a big fight and Boches were in superior number. Rochwell reported having seen Prince fall but Prince came in a few minutes ago. Balsley is over half and hour late. He was a little behind the others and may have fallen in with all the Boches. Cowden too is missing but they didn’t see him in fight.

Yesterday there was an alert but by the time we could get ready the Boches were over the field. The bombs were dropping as we left. One went off to my right as I was leaving the ground and I was glad to jump into the air. By the time we gained their altitude they were ficing [sic] over their lines. There’s not much to do against an outfit like that unless one knows long before that they are coming.

A short time after we had come down and before we started on our second sortie over lines we saw a distressing accident. Two men went up in a large Brequet. It rocks and floats as if it were not meant for the air. At fifty meters high the pilote tried a very steep turn. The big thing flopped over, made a swerve and nose down hit the earth. There was a
sickening thud. Both men were killed instantly but before any one could reach them the machine took fire and for half an hour we had to look on being unable to do a thing.

Later: Cowden showed up at a field nearby with engine trouble or something. Balsley came down back of the lines (Chez nous) wounded in the thigh. I feel relieved for I was afraid he was dead. Here comes Cowden now — I’ll see what news he has. — Nothing. He had engine trouble.
I’ve seen Lovell several times. He’s looking fine and always the same charming fellow. He’s leaving to morrow for aviation. Wish he were with us now. Guess you’ll see him when he’s in Pauam.
Have been hoping to hear from you but have had no letter in a long time. Do write.

closer.seg: We are apt to leave here for a field nearer the lines.
